subject: Re: [junit] More example JUnit code
msgSnippet: ... I m not sure what you mean by generality.  If I were to re-extract the constants, what would that allow me to do that I can t now, or what costs would I
messageBody:
2010/8/23 Cédric Beust ♔ <cedric@...>:
> You're losing quite a bit of generality since you are inlining all the
> constants.

I'm not sure what you mean by generality. If I were to re-extract the
constants, what would that allow me to do that I can't now, or what
costs would I save?

> You are also creating and recreating a lot of similar objects all
> the time, there's a lot of DRY violation in your code. Your code is a good
> first version, but it needs some refactoring.

Version A is more than twice as long as Version B. In Version B, we have:

assertEquals(f(1, 1), f(1, 1).reduce());

To know what this does, with no familiarity with JUnit, I need to look at

A) The definition of the f function (which is just syntactic sugar).
B) The definition of assertEquals

In Version A:

Assert.assertEquals(input.reduce(), expected);

To know what this does, with no familiarity with TestNG, I need to look at:

A) The parameter list, to see that these are input parameters
B) The TestNG manual, to see how these inputs are generated
C) The @Test(dataProvider = "reduceData") line, to see which provider
is being used
D) The multiplicationData method, to see which data is being passed in
E) The F_1_1 constant, to see what it contains
F) The definition of assertEquals

The next developer to work on your project is more likely to notice
this cost in mental indirection long before they appreciate any wins
in "Don't Repeat Yourself"*

David Saff

* They may even notice that while Version A has three fewer repeated
calls to assertEquals, it has seven _more_ repeated calls to new
Object[]

>
> Again, a class such as Factor is a perfect target for parameterized testing
> since the logic of the testing doesn't change (verify that f1.operation(f2)
> equals f3), only the data does.
>
> --
> Cédric
>
>
> On Mon, Aug 23, 2010 at 6:51 AM, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
>
>> 2010/8/22 Cédric Beust ♔ <cedric@...>:
>> > Simon,
>> >
>> > Actually, I was wrong: using @BeforeClass will break your tests. Since
>> JUnit
>> > reinstantiates a brand new class before each test method, only the first
>> > method will get the correct values for these fields. Subsequent methods
>> will
>> > see null.
>>
>> @BeforeClass only works on static values, and should be matched with
>> an @AfterClass.  It is very rare to see @BeforeClass used for set-up
>> of lightweight data values.
>>
>> > Anyway, these values are constants, so they should be static final. Which
>> > solves the problem and also gets rid of @Before and @After.
>> >
>> > About the fields: what bothers me with this approach is that you're
>> exposing
>> > a lot of fields to all your test methods and they only use a very small
>> > subset of these. In effect, fields are like global variables and they
>> make
>> > it harder for someone coming to improve your class to understand exactly
>> > what fields are okay to modify and which tests need to be updated as
>> well. I
>> > like to keep the data needed by each test method as local as possible to
>> > avoid this kind of problem.
>> >
>> > Parameterized tests help a lot with this kind of locality, and they turn
>> out
>> > to be a great match for this particular problem.
>> >
>> > With all this in mind, here is my version (TestNG syntax, porting to
>> JUnit
>> > is left as an exercise to the reader):
>> >
>> > public class FractionTest {
>> >
>> >  // A few useful constants
>> >  private static final Fraction F_1_1 = new Fraction(1, 1);
>> >  private static final Fraction F_1_2 = new Fraction(1, 2);
>> >  private static final Fraction F_1_3 = new Fraction(1, 3);
>> >  private static final Fraction F_2_1 = new Fraction(2, 1);
>> >
>> >  /**
>> >   * The data set used to verify reduction, the last parameter of each
>> >   * row is the expected value.
>> >   */
>> >  @DataProvider
>> >  public Object[][] reduceData() {
>> >    return new Object[][] {
>> >      new Object[] { F_1_1, F_1_1 },
>> >      new Object[] { new Fraction(2, 2), F_1_1 },
>> >      new Object[] { new Fraction(4, 2), F_2_1 },
>> >      // ...
>> >    };
>> >  }
>> >
>> >  @Test(dataProvider = "reduceData")
>> >  public void verifyReduce(Fraction input, Fraction expected) {
>> >    Assert.assertEquals(input.reduce(), expected);
>> >  }
>> >
>> >  /**
>> >   * The data set used to verify multiplication, the last parameter of
>> each
>> >   * row is the expected value after rediction
>> >   */
>> >  @DataProvider
>> >  public Object[][] multiplicationData() {
>> >    return new Object[][] {
>> >      new Object[] { F_1_1, F_1_1, F_1_1 },
>> >      new Object[] { new Fraction(2, 2), new Fraction(3, 2), new
>> Fraction(3,
>> > 2) },
>> >      // ...
>> >    };
>> >  }
>> >
>> >  @Test(dataProvider = "multiplicationData")
>> >  public void verifyReduce(Fraction f1, Fraction f2, Fraction expected) {
>> >    // Assuming that multiply() will call reduce() before returning its
>> > result
>> >    Assert.Equals(f1.multiply(f2), expected);
>> >    Assert.Equals(f2.multiply(f1), expected);
>> >  }
>> > }
>>
>> I'd replace your 49 lines of code with these 17, without loss of
>> extensibility or coverage:
>>
>> public class FractionTest {
>>  private Fraction f(int num, int denom) {
>>   return new Fraction(num, denom);
>>  }
>>
>>  @Test public void reduce() {
>>   assertEquals(f(1, 1), f(1, 1).reduce());
>>   assertEquals(f(1, 1), f(2, 2).reduce());
>>   assertEquals(f(2, 1), f(4, 2).reduce());
>>  }
>>
>>  @Test public void multiply() {
>>    // Assuming that multiply() will call reduce() before returning its
>> result
>>    assertEquals(f(1, 1), f(1, 1).multiply(f(1, 1)));
>>   assertEquals(f(3, 2), f(2, 2).multiply(f(3, 2)));
>>  }
>> }
>>
>>   David Saff
>>
>> >
>> > You can probably see how parameterized tests improve the locality of your
>> > tests and how adding values to extend the coverage is trivial.
>> >
>> > Also note that this is a great example of how misleading code coverage
>> can
>> > be: you would get 100% test coverage if you only returned 1 data set in
>> each
>> > data provider, but your tests would be very poor. Adding values to your
>> data
>> > provider will do nothing for your code coverage but it will considerably
>> > improve the quality of your tests.
>> >
>> > --
>> > Cédric
>> >
>> >
>> > On Sun, Aug 22, 2010 at 6:11 PM, Simon Chappell <
>> > simonpeterchappell@...> wrote:
>> >
>> >> Cedric,
>> >>
>> >> Good points.
>> >>
>> >> 1. I'm not used to the @BeforeClass. I will make that change, as it is a
>> >> better fit.
>> >> 2. The assigning of nulls is just to emphasize cleaning up after
>> yourself.
>> >> I
>> >> agree that it's technically unnecessary.
>> >> 3. Let me think about the parameterized thing. I think for eight values,
>> >> with their descriptive names, it brings more value leaving them as they
>> >> are,
>> >> although I may change where they are defined.
>> >>
>> >> Thank you for you considered points. Hopefully this will help us all
>> >> sharpen
>> >> our JUnit writing.
>> >>
>> >> Simon
>> >>
>> >>
>> >> 2010/8/22 Cédric Beust ♔ <cedric@...>
>> >>
>> >> >
>> >> >
>> >> > Hi Simon,
>> >> >
>> >> > A few quick questions/remarks:
>> >> >
>> >> > - Why do you initialize the fractions in @Before and not @BeforeClass,
>> >> > since you don't seem to ever modify them?
>> >> > - Why assigning them to null in @After?
>> >> > - Given the nature of your tests, I would probably use parameterized
>> >> > tests to supply only the data that each test needs instead of making
>> >> these
>> >> > eight fields available to all the test methods all the time.
>> >> >
>> >> > --
>> >> > Cédric
>> >> >
>> >> >
>> >> > On Sun, Aug 22, 2010 at 3:47 PM, Simon Chappell <
>> >> > simonpeterchappell@... <simonpeterchappell%40gmail.com>> wrote:
>> >> >
>> >> > > Following up on my previous offering of example JUnit code, I have
>> >> pushed
>> >> > a
>> >> > > project called Fraction to GitHub. This implements classic
>> mathematical
>> >> > > fractions and was written in a test first manner and has documented
>> >> unit
>> >> > > tests to help those learning JUnit see one style (my style!) of test
>> >> > > implementation.
>> >> > >
>> >> > > The code may be found at:
>> >> > >
>> >> > > http://github.com/simonpeter/Fraction
>> >> > >
>> >> > > I hope that you find it useful.
>> >> > >
>> >> > > Simon
>> >> > > (one of the JUnit mailing list moderators)
>> >> > >
>> >> > > --
>> >> > > simonpeter.org | simonpeter.com | newlife-upc.org
